title: How companies explain their C.E.O.s’ big pay packages in the pandemic.
description: The gap between executive compensation and average worker pay has been growing for decades. Chief executives of big companies now make, on average, 320 times as much as their typical worker, according to the Economic Policy Institute. In 1989, that ratio was 61 to 1.
content: The gap between executive compensation and average worker pay has been growing for decades. Chief executives of big companies now make, on average, 320 times as much as their typical worker, according to the Economic Policy Institute. In 1989, that ratio was 61 to 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Rachel Cusk’s New Novel Turns Up the Heat at a Private Artist’s Retreat
description: “Second Place” borrows its story line from a 1930s-era memoir about D.H. Lawrence, but its themes are quintessential Cusk.
content: You know when you’re reading a page of Rachel Cusk’s fiction. Her narrators tug insistently if coolly at the central knots of being. They analyze every emotion as if it were freshly invented. Nothing is extraneous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: Why the Meaning of ‘Infrastructure’ Matters So Much
description: The definition has always depended on what a society is trying to accomplish.
content: In June 1982, President Ronald Reagan delivered a fire-eating speech before the British House of Commons that is best remembered for his prediction that democratic nations would triumph and communism would end up on “the ash heap of history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: Why The New York Times Is Retiring the Term ‘Op-Ed’
description: Our mission to stimulate thought and provoke discussion on public problems remains the same.
content: The first Op-Ed page in The New York Times greeted the world on Sept. 21, 1970. It was so named because it appeared opposite the editorial page and not (as many still believe) because it would offer views contrary to the paper’s. Inevitably, it would do that, too, since its founders were putting out a welcome mat for ideas and arguments from many points on the political, social and cultural spectrums from outside the walls of The Times — to stimulate thought and provoke discussion of public problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: In California, a campaign to oust Gov. Gavin Newsom qualifies for the ballot.
description: The 1.6 million voters who signed a petition for the Republican-led recall effort have 30 business days to ask to have their names removed if they so choose.
content: Fueled by partisan fury and a backlash against pandemic shutdowns, a Republican-led campaign to oust Gov. Gavin Newsom of California has officially qualified for the ballot, setting the stage for the second recall election in the state’s history, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: When Guards in New York City’s Jails Lie About Use of Force
description: An analysis of a newly released database of disciplinary records shows that violence by officers continues to be a problem in the  system.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Mia Neal and Jamika Wilson are the first Black women to win for hair and makeup.
description: They are also the first ever to be nominated in the category since it was introduced in 1981.
content: In what may shape up as a night of firsts, Mia Neal and Jamika Wilson became the first Black women to win an Oscar for best hair and makeup for their work on “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Why Some Black Democrats Haven’t Embraced a Voting Rights Push
description: In the South, Black Democrats describe a party too slow in combating Republican voting limits. And Black lawmakers are wary that a major elections bill could reduce their power in Congress.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — The right to vote is what Frank Figgers fought for in the 1960s as a student at a racially segregated high school in Jackson, Miss. It is what Medgar Evers died for when he was shot to death outside his home in the city in 1963, after his work with the state N.A.A.C.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Homeland Security Will Assess How It Identifies Extremism in Its Ranks
description: The department that works to prevent domestic terrorism threats will conduct an internal review as part of a larger effort to combat extremist ideology in the federal government.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security will undergo an internal review to root out white supremacy and extremism in its ranks as part of a larger effort to combat extremist ideology in the federal government, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Opens Inquiry Into Louisville Police
description: The force had come under scrutiny after the police killed a Black woman, Breonna Taylor, in a botched raid last year.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced on Monday a sweeping Justice Department investigation into the Louisville, Ky., police and the county government there, the second time in a week that the department has opened a civil investigation into a police force that prompted national furor over the killing of an unarmed Black person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Madison Bumgarner Throws a No-Hitter. Kind Of.
description: In a game limited to seven innings as part of a doubleheader, the Arizona lefty got a shutout but was not credited with a no-no.
content: Madison Bumgarner took the mound in Atlanta on Sunday afternoon for a game that was scheduled to last seven innings. Bumgarner went the distance for the Arizona Diamondbacks to beat the Braves, 7-0. His official statistics will reflect a victory, a shutout and a complete game — but not the distinctive part of the achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Katie Rogers
title: Congress prepares for an unusual presidential address.
description: A president’s address to a joint session of Congress is typically a crowded affair, as lawmakers from both parties, and their guests, pack the House floor. But President Biden’s speech on Wednesday, his first before Congress since his inauguration, will look very different.
content: A president’s address to a joint session of Congress is typically a crowded affair, as lawmakers from both parties, and their guests, pack the House floor. But President Biden’s speech on Wednesday, his first before Congress since his inauguration, will look very different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France Seeks Change in Law After Outrage Over Verdict in Anti-Semitic Killing
description: The proposed bill would prevent intoxication being used as a basis for a plea of insanity and was prompted by a verdict allowing the killer of a Jewish woman to avoid trial.
content: PARIS — The French government plans to introduce a bill aimed at closing a legal loophole that allowed the man who killed a Jewish woman in an anti-Semitic frenzy in 2017 to escape trial because a court found that he was in a delirious state brought on by cannabis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.8 Million Homes in California
description: A 1934 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an A-frame retreat in Lake Arrowhead and a traditional home in San Diego.
content: This house, owned by the seller for three decades, is a well-preserved example of the 1920s and 1930s Spanish-style homes for which Los Angeles is known. The original colorful tiles in the bathrooms and kitchen have been carefully maintained, and original built-ins with decorative flourishes abound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Race and the Coming Liberal Crackup
description: Our racialized politics will produce a conservative resurgence.
content: Americans breathed a collective sigh of relief last week after Derek Chauvin was convicted of murdering George Floyd. The crime was heinous, the verdict just, the moral neat. If you think that systemic racism is the defining fact of race relations in 21st-century America, then Chauvin’s knee on Floyd’s neck is its defining image.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines could benefit when the E.U. eases restrictions on travel.
description: The European Commission chief expects provisions opening the door for vaccinated Americans, and the industry sees opportunity.
content: U.S. airlines have been bolstered by the return of customers eager to travel within the country or just outside its borders, but the nation’s largest carriers are still lamenting the loss of two particularly lucrative parts of the business: international and corporate travel. At least one of those could rebound this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Africa’s slow vaccine rollout could endanger millions of lives — on and off the continent.
content: Of the one billion shots given around the world, 82 percent have been given in high- and upper-middle-income countries. Only 0.2 percent of doses have been administered in low-income countries — pockets of infection that can produce variants that put us all in danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott and Wesley Morris
title: What Did That Oscars Show Say About Movies? Our Critics Puzzle It Out.
description: The anticlimactic night was in many ways not too different from previous Academy Awards, and it showed the organization was willing to change only so much.
content: On the morning after a very odd Oscars, we asked A.O. Scott, co-chief film critic, and Wesley Morris, critic at large, to discuss what they made of it all. The ceremony was always going to be unusual because of pandemic-related limitations, but it ended in one of the biggest letdowns in memory: when best actor, not best picture, was the final award of the night, and the winner was an absent Anthony Hopkins, not the expected Chadwick Boseman. Here’s what our critics said:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s Foreign Minister, in Leaked Tape, Says Revolutionary Guards Set Policies
description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, described a rivalry with a powerful and widely revered military leader, Qassim Suleimani.
content: In a leaked audiotape that offers a glimpse into the behind-the-scenes power struggles of Iranian leaders, Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said the Revolutionary Guards Corps call the shots, overruling many government decisions and ignoring advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Philip’s Death Adds New Urgency to U.K. Monarchy’s Transition Plans
description: Queen Elizabeth II is increasingly withdrawing to Windsor Castle, royal watchers say, while Prince Charles is stepping forward.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II turned 95 last week, four days after burying her husband, Prince Philip, and with him the partnership that guided Britain’s royal family for nearly 70 years. Now, as the queen faces the future alone, her son and heir, Prince Charles, is reshaping the family to carry on after her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Is the Best Way to Stop Abusive Language Online?
description: Should social media companies be more accountable for punishing users who use discriminatory, abusive or threatening language?
content: How often do you encounter racist, sexist or otherwise discriminatory language online in posts or comments? Do you think abusive language is a serious problem that social media companies, like Twitter and Facebook, should do a better job of addressing? What consequences should there be for users who post these kinds of comments?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Surging virus variants push the Philippines over a million total cases.
description: MANILA — The Philippines surpassed the one million mark on Monday in the total number of coronavirus cases it has reported, as the country struggles with newer, deadlier forms of the virus.
content: MANILA — The Philippines surpassed the one million mark on Monday in the total number of coronavirus cases it has reported, as the country struggles with newer, deadlier forms of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Fans come out in prepandemic numbers for an Australian rules football match.
description: MELBOURNE, Australia — More than 78,000 people attended an Australian rules football match in Melbourne on Sunday night in what is believed to be the world’s biggest crowd at a sporting event since the coronavirus pandemic began.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — More than 78,000 people attended an Australian rules football match in Melbourne on Sunday night in what is believed to be the world’s biggest crowd at a sporting event since the coronavirus pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Hundreds Are Forced to Evacuate From Western Arizona Wildfire
description: The Flag Fire has consumed 600 acres in the Hualapai Mountains in northwestern Arizona and prompted the evacuation of about 200 households, the authorities said.
content: A wildfire in the pine tree-covered Hualapai Mountains of northwestern Arizona, which continued to burn on Monday, has forced the evacuation of a resort, county park and hundreds of homes, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Klinenberg
title: Infrastructure Isn’t Really About Roads. It’s About the Society We Want.
description: By that standard, even President Biden’s $2 trillion proposal falls short.
content: Until recently, the question of what counts as infrastructure was an academic matter. Today, thanks to President Biden’s $2 trillion proposal to upgrade and transform the nation’s infrastructure, it’s the most important issue in American political and economic life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: The Covid-19 Oscars: Not Masked but Still Muffled
description: A stripped-down ceremony stripped out too much of what makes the show, for better or worse, worth watching.
content: The producers of the 2021 Oscars had said that they planned to make the annual telecast more like a film. They didn’t succeed at that, but they did change things up. Sunday’s broadcast on ABC was more like a cross between the Golden Globes and the closing-night banquet of a long, exhausting convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Case on Carrying Guns in Public
description: The justices, who have not issued a major Second Amendment ruling since 2010, will consider a challenge to a longstanding New York gun control law.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would review a longstanding New York law that imposes strict limits on carrying guns outside the home, setting the stage for its first major Second Amendment decision in more than a decade — and the first to be decided by the court’s newly expanded conservative majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Marco Rubio’s ‘Woke Capital’ Tantrum
description: Republicans are mad at big business, but not mad enough to raise taxes.
content: Senator Marco Rubio is extremely mad at corporations for “bending a knee to woke progressive craziness,” and he’s going to do, well, something about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Carol Rosenberg
title: Supreme Court to Rule on Whether C.I.A. Black Sites Are State Secrets
description: A Guantánamo detainee is seeking information from two former government contractors in connection with a Polish criminal inquiry into a facility there.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether the government can block a detainee at Guantánamo Bay from obtaining information from two former C.I.A. contractors involved in torturing him on the ground that it would expose state secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: What’s Behind the Apple-Facebook Feud?
description: The fight between the two tech giants might remodel the internet as we know it.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sing-Rap Generation Branches Out
description: How melody has continued to reshape hip-hop via the work of Polo G, Rod Wave, Lil Tjay and more rising artists.
content: The No. 1 song in the United States is Polo G’s “Rapstar”; Rod Wave’s recent album “SoulFly” recently debuted at the top of the Billboard album chart; and one of the most in-demand collaborators in hip-hop is Lil Tjay. The current sing-rap generation is thriving, and utilizing a variety of approaches, from saccharine pop to gospel-esque blues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Long Before Her ‘Minari’ Oscar, Yuh-Jung Youn Won South Korea’s Heart
description: Ms. Youn is the first Asian woman to win the best supporting actress Oscar since 1957. But it’s her life story — as well as her characters — that made her award resonate among Koreans.
content: SEOUL — “Minari,” the critically acclaimed movie about a hard-luck family of Korean immigrants in the United States, was not exactly a commercial blockbuster in South Korea: Fewer than a million people watched it in 54 days of screening across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong and Singapore set a new date for the start of a long-delayed travel bubble.
description: The governments of Singapore and Hong Kong said on Monday that a long-delayed travel bubble between the two Asian financial centers would begin next month, allowing travelers on designated flights to bypass quarantine.
content: The governments of Singapore and Hong Kong said on Monday that a long-delayed travel bubble between the two Asian financial centers would begin next month, allowing travelers on designated flights to bypass quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: jaunty
description: This word has appeared in 75 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Aid for India’s coronavirus crisis.
content: American tourists who have been fully vaccinated against Covid-19 will be able to visit countries in the E.U. starting this summer, the head of the bloc’s executive body said in an interview with The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Salsa Macha Hecho en Los Angeles
description: The masa purveyor Masienda has released a line of three potent salsas machas.
content: So you’ve used chile crisp for just about everything. Maybe it’s time to try a different chile-fueled oil-based condiment. Three intriguing varieties of Mexican salsa macha have been created by Masienda, a supplier of traditional Mexican ingredients. They’re crunchy, ruddy with oil and chiles, and offer some sweetness to play off the heat. Guajillo-cranberry-hazelnut is chewy and earthy; chipotle-coffee-peanut is chunky, nutty and hot; and arbol-nori-sesame made also with Sichuan peppercorns has funky sizzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and David Gelles
title: Why These C.E.O.s Got Paid So Much in the Pandemic
description: Companies defend stratospheric pay for their leaders.
content: The Times’s David Gelles gives DealBook the backstory to his recent front-page article about rising C.E.O. pay during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amisha Padnani
title: Hester Ford, Oldest American, Dies
description: She was believed to be either 115 or 116. She experienced two pandemics and two world wars and lived under 21 presidents.
content: Hester Ford, who was believed to have been the oldest American, living long enough to have experienced two pandemics, both world wars, Jim Crow discrimination, civil rights movements and the elections of 21 presidents, died on Saturday at her home in Charlotte, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Firsts and other breakthroughs at the Oscars.
description: This year’s Academy Award nominees were historically among the event’s more diverse lineups: Seventy women earned nods across 23 categories, and nine people of color were nominated for their acting.
content: This year’s Academy Award nominees were historically among the event’s more diverse lineups: Seventy women earned nods across 23 categories, and nine people of color were nominated for their acting.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 26, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 26, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 26, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: After Covid Upended a Dying Woman’s Rome Dream, Her Twin Stepped In
description: When Lisa Maksym tested positive for the coronavirus, she was forced to stop cancer treatments, threatening a long-planned return to Rome. Her sister hatched a plan.
content: The cancer that was first detected in her breasts had spread to her bones, lungs and liver. The pandemic had shut down travel nearly everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Zoom Discussion of Anthony Bourdain’s Irreverent Travels
description: The writer’s assistant, Laurie Woolever, will discuss their travel book with The New Yorker writer Helen Rosner.
content: Laurie Woolever, a writer who was the assistant to the peripatetic writer and television personality Anthony Bourdain, has assembled an offbeat yet practical travel guide that the two of them started working on not long before he died in 2018. She soldiered on to assemble the new book, “World Travel: An Irreverent Guide,” based on Mr. Bourdain’s writings and experiences in more than 40 countries. His observations cover the irreverent descriptor with wit to spare, hers touch on practicalities, though you’d never mistake this for Fodor. To better understand it and reminisce about Mr. Bourdain there will be a Zoom discussion of the book with Ms. Woolever and The New Yorker writer Helen Rosner, held by the Museum of Food and Drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Still Getting Your Head Around Digital Currency? So Are Central Bankers.
description: If you are trying to grasp Bitcoin and understand what China’s digital yuan means, America’s Federal Reserve is right there with you.
content: America’s Federal Reserve says it is in no rush to issue a digital currency, but it is coming under intense and increasing pressure to research and understand the design and potential of digital money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Make lemon-saffron chicken and potatoes, roasted salmon with peas and radishes, or an asparagus and scallion salad.
content: Good morning. How are you? It’s possible you’re ecstatic, vaccinated, eager to return to some sense of normalcy, or at any rate to a state in which you’re not just scared all the time. It’s possible you’re exhausted, worn down by the months of uncertainty, the lack of work, the lack of human contact. It’s possible that you’re both — or that you’re neither. This pandemic is grabbing at each of us differently, and its effects will be with us long after herd immunity arrives. But no one I’m talking to seems utterly content, right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Family of North Carolina Man Killed by Deputies Is Shown 20-Second Video
description: The family of Andrew Brown Jr. watched a snippet of his final moments, but that hasn’t stopped the demands to publicly release body camera footage of the fatal shooting.
content: ELIZABETH CITY, N.C. — Despite appeals from the governor and other elected leaders, community activists and the family of a man who was killed by sheriff’s deputies, the authorities in a North Carolina coastal county had not publicly released body camera footage of the deadly encounter as of Monday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: The Justice Department will investigate the Louisville police, Garland says.
description: The Louisville police came under fire after officers raided the home of a Black medical worker named Breonna Taylor last March and shot her to death.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced a sweeping Justice Department investigation on Monday into the Louisville, Ky., metro police and the county government there, the second time in a week that the department has opened a civil investigation into a police force that prompted national furor for the killing of an unarmed Black person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: ‘Slime Language 2,’ by Young Thug and Friends, Reaches No. 1
description: The compilation featuring the Atlanta rapper and various artists from his Young Stoner Life label bested Taylor Swift for the top spot on Billboard’s album chart.
content: Mixtape, playlist or compilation album — what’s the difference?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Appalachian Trail Killer Found Not Guilty by Reason of Insanity
description: A judge found James L. Jordan not guilty by reason of insanity in the fatal stabbing of Ronald S. Sanchez Jr. along the trail in 2019.
content: In 2019, Ronald S. Sanchez Jr., an Iraq war veteran, set off to find peace in nature along the Appalachian Trail, a quest that millions of others take each year on the long route through mountains and forests from Georgia to Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Paul Oscher, Blues Musician in Muddy Waters’s Band, Dies at 74
description: He played harmonica, guitar and piano, often all at the same time. He died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Kevin McCarthy, four months after Jan. 6, is still playing defense over Trump.
description: Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, was in an uncharacteristically dark place after the Capitol siege of Jan. 6.
content: Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, was in an uncharacteristically dark place after the Capitol siege of Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Kim Mulkey Leaves Baylor for L.S.U.
description: Mulkey, who won three national titles in 21 seasons with the Bears, will return to the state where she made her name.
content: Louisiana State scored a major women’s basketball coup on Sunday when it hired Kim Mulkey, who won three national championships in 21 years at Baylor, as its new coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff
title: U.S. Population Over Last Decade Grew at Slowest Rate Since 1930s
description: With immigration leveling off and a declining birthrate, the United States may be entering an era of substantially lower population growth, demographers said.
content: Over the past decade, the United States population grew at the second slowest rate since the government started counting in 1790, the Census Bureau reported on Monday, a remarkable slackening that was driven by a slowdown in immigration and a declining birthrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: On the Oscars Red Carpet: A Lot of Style, Little Substance
description: A return to in-person awards meant a return to fashion form for many celebrities. Have we learned nothing from the past year?
content: The 93rd annual Academy Awards were a night of historic firsts: first woman of color to win the directing Oscar; first Black women to win the makeup and hairstyling Oscar; oldest woman ever to win an Oscar; first Korean actor to win an Oscar. But in at least one area it was more like same-old, same-old: the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Athas
title: 5 Takeaways From the New Food Allergy Law
description: Sesame becomes a “major allergen,” joining milk, eggs, fish, shellfish, tree nuts, peanuts, wheat and soybeans.
content: If you have a food allergy, or your child does, chances are you spend a lot of time reading labels to figure out whether something will trigger an allergic reaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company Challenges NASA Over SpaceX Moon Lander Deal
description: The space agency picked Elon Musk’s company over two other bidders to take its astronauts back to the lunar surface.
content: Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk, two of the richest men in the world, both with dreams of leading humanity out into the solar system, are fighting over the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Yuh-Jung Youn becomes the first Korean woman in Oscar history to win best supporting actress.
description: “How can I win over Glenn Close?” Youn said while accepting the award for her role in “Minari.” “Tonight, I have just a little bit luck, I think, maybe.”
content: After the Korean actress Yuh-Jung Youn’s delightfully hilarious BAFTA acceptance speech earlier this month, the Academy gave the 73-years-young “Minari” grandmother the chance to deliver another Sunday night when it selected her as its best supporting actress. It is the first time a Korean actress has ever won an acting Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: The C.I.A.’s Top Technologist Is Uncomfortable With Facebook
description: Dawn Meyerriecks talks spy gear and why Hollywood and Silicon Valley play a critical role in national security.
content: The Central Intelligence Agency poaches puppeteers from Hollywood and partners with big tech firms from Silicon Valley. It has to, says the agency’s top technologist, Dawn Meyerriecks, if it wants cutting-edge drones, hidden cameras, and deep cover that can bypass biometric scans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Airline Bars Alaska State Senator Over Mask Policy Violation
description: Alaska Airlines said it had suspended State Senator Lora Reinbold from flying because she refused to comply with its mask rules.
content: Alaska Airlines has suspended an Alaska state lawmaker from its flights for violating its mask policies, the company said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liaquat Ahamed
title: Amy Klobuchar on Breaking Up Giant Corporations
description: Klobuchar’s “Antitrust” looks at the history of policy toward trusts and monopolies, and calls for revitalized efforts to bring economic titans under control.
content: ANTITRUSTTaking on Monopoly Power From the Gilded Age to the Digital AgeBy Amy Klobuchar
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: SHMOO was a character from “Li’l Abner,” a satirical comic strip by the cartoonist Al Capp that ran from 1934 to 1977.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: India’s New Covid Mystery
description: Many people in India thought the country had escaped the worst of Covid-19. What happened?
content: There is a new Covid-19 mystery in India, and it is far grimmer than the first one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Jack Nicas
title: Breaking Point: How Mark Zuckerberg and Tim Cook Became Foes
description: The chief executives of Facebook and Apple have opposing visions for the future of the internet. Their differences are set to escalate this week.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — At a confab for tech and media moguls in Sun Valley, Idaho, in July 2019, Timothy D. Cook of Apple and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook sat down to repair their fraying relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Less Is (Considerably) More for Vladimir Guerrero Jr.
description: The Blue Jays star sought help from a trainer — and his grandmother — to reimagine his body. He’s down 42 pounds and his O.P.S. is up 244 points.
content: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The 2020 season wasn’t over yet when Vladimir Guerrero Jr. realized what he needed to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Is Sentenced to Another Year in Custody in Iran
description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian dual citizen who was released from detention last month, was handed the sentence and a one-year travel ban on new charges of “propaganda activities.”
content: LONDON — Last month, it seemed as if Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe’s five-year ordeal of detention in Iran was drawing to a close when she was released from house arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: ‘Soul’ continues Pixar’s dominance in awards season.
description: The movie featured the studio’s first Black protagonist (voiced by Jamie Foxx).
content: “Soul,” the Pixar story of an aspiring jazz musician hovering between life and death, was named best animated feature, a win that was expected even though “Wolfwalkers,” a Celtic fantasy from the Irish studio Cartoon Saloon, had its partisans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: On Majorca, a Wellness Retreat Whose Design Was a Family Affair
description: How a pair of siblings, him an architect and her a fashion designer, worked together to help shape their father’s latest study in soothing minimalism.
content: There are architects who have shaped certain places in such singular and profound ways — Luis Barragán and Mexico City, Albert Frey and Palm Springs — that it’s hard to think of one without the other. Increasingly, the same is true of Antoni Esteva and Majorca, situated some 130 miles from the Spanish mainland in the sapphire waters of the Mediterranean. Over the past five decades, Esteva, who was born on the island, has dreamed up or transformed dozens of its buildings, from the local artist Miquel Barceló’s home and atelier — which incorporates a 13th-century lookout tower — to the reimagined 18th-century farmhouse that holds the cultish country hotel Son Gener. In 2010, he embarked on a restoration of the artist Joan Miró’s former home in Palma, Majorca’s capital, reorienting the rooms so as to redirect the gaze to the garden. If there is a common thread running through his work, it’s his fondness for employing natural materials and the resulting structures’ tendency to complement, and sometimes even disappear into, the landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: The Academy Has Spoken. Now It’s Your Turn.
description: Tell us what you think about this year’s Oscars.
content: On Sunday, Hollywood’s upper crust (plus a few lucky outsiders) gathered to celebrate one another — oh, and the films they made. Despite a year of shuttered theaters and a scarcity of red carpets, the show did go on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: N.B.A. Power Rankings: The Utah Jazz Are Hitting All the Right Notes
description: Once a season, Marc Stein provides a more detailed assessment of the N.B.A.’s 1-to-30 landscape than the standings do.
content: The funky basketball calendar in use this season has thrown everyone off in the N.B.A. That includes writers unaccustomed to covering a regular season broken into halves, with the All-Star Game and trade deadline in March and a postseason that doesn’t begin until mid-May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Picassos of the American South
description: William Edmondson and other self-taught artists remind us of how genius somehow finds a way.
content: NASHVILLE — I’ve never been all that interested in Picasso, but the show at the Frist Art Museum here would be my first chance to see an entire exhibition of Picasso’s figures in the flesh, so I rushed to buy tickets before it sold out. Maybe these paintings, drawings and sculptures would be what made me fall in love with the terrible, brilliant Minotaur that was Pablo Picasso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Crohn’s Disease Is on the Rise
description: Many think the abdominal disorder starts in childhood, but it can occur at any age and is becoming more prevalent throughout the world.
content: Shelley Martin, a Manhattan accountant, was in her mid-60s when she learned after a routine colonoscopy that she had Crohn’s disease, a chronic inflammatory disorder characterized by abdominal pain and diarrhea. She said when friends learned of her diagnosis, several said “How can that be? Crohn’s starts in childhood.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Terrorist Group Steps Into Venezuela as Lawlessness Grows
description: With Venezuela in shambles, criminals and insurgents run large stretches of the nation’s territory. We traveled through one of the regions under their control.
content: GUARERO, Venezuela — They bring drinking water to residents in the arid scrublands, teach farming workshops and offer medical checkups. They mediate land disputes, fine cattle rustlers, settle divorces, investigate crimes and punish thieves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Daniel Kaluuya wins best supporting actor.
description: The British actor played a Chicago leader of the Black Panther Party in “Judas and the Black Messiah.”
content: Daniel Kaluuya won the Academy Award for best supporting actor for his nuanced portrayal of Fred Hampton in “Judas and the Black Messiah,” beating out his co-star, Lakeith Stanfield, who was also nominated in the category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Wary of Donor Disclosure Requirement for Charities
description: The case, from California, could affect the regulation of “dark money” in political contests.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday seemed skeptical of California’s demand that charities soliciting contributions in the state report the identities of their major donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: A Minneapolis High School Football Team and Its Coach Move On
description: Charles Adams, a former police officer, and the Minneapolis North team are warily moving forward after the Derek Chauvin verdict offered a rebuke to one police killing in their community.
content: Third-degree murder. Guilty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela Gerson
title: My Grandparents’ Immigration Lies Shaped My Father’s View of Justice
description: Years after fleeing Europe, my father saw himself in the Dreamers of today.
content: I felt like I was spying on my grandparents’ lies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘United Shades of America’ and a Presidential Address
description: W. Kamau Bell’s documentary series returns with an episode on policing. And President Biden addresses a joint session of Congress.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 26-May 2. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: With No Frills or Celebrities, Cookpad Is a Global Go-To for Recipes
description: Born in Japan and a hit around the world, the recipe-sharing site has been less successful in America. Yet it has a small, fervent following among immigrants.
content: There are unspoken expectations the digital realm tends to place on recipes: They should photograph beautifully. They should have the mass appeal to go viral. And they should be written by a charismatic cook with a huge Instagram following and an adorable dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italy’s Problem With School Dropouts Goes From Bad to Worse in Pandemic
description: Even before the coronavirus hit, Italy had among the worst dropout rates in Europe. But closed schools and online classes have pushed students out in ever higher numbers.
content: NAPLES — Francesca Nardi never liked school, or thought she was particularly good at it, but with the help of teachers and classmates she had managed to stick around until 11th grade. When the pandemic hit, though, she found herself lost in online classes, unable to understand her teacher through the tablet the school gave her. She was failing, likely to get left back, and planning to drop out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Why California’s Growth Has Slowed (and Why Demographers Aren’t Surprised)
description: California will lose a congressional seat based on new census data, in part because of birthrate and immigration declines.
content: For generations, California has been America’s boomtown writ large, with a population that nearly doubled to some 40 million in the last four decades alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Double Amputee’s Hopes for the Olympics Are in Jeopardy
description: Blake Leeper qualified for the world championships in track and field in 2019, but officials maintain his running blades make him too tall.
content: Blake Leeper, one of the world’s fastest double-amputee athletes, will have to race on a significantly smaller set of running blades if he wants to compete for a spot on the United States Olympic team, World Athletics ruled Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The United States will send virus-ravaged India materials to make vaccines.
description: The Biden administration, under increasing pressure to address a devastating surge of the coronavirus in India, said on Sunday that it had removed impediments to the export of raw materials for vaccines and would also supply India with therapeutics, rapid diagnostic test kits, ventilators and personal protective gear.
content: The Biden administration, under increasing pressure to address a devastating surge of the coronavirus in India, said on Sunday that it had removed impediments to the export of raw materials for vaccines and would also supply India with therapeutics, rapid diagnostic test kits, ventilators and personal protective gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Anthony Hopkins shocks by winning best actor over Chadwick Boseman.
description: The Welsh actor delivered a memorable performance in “The Father” as a man suffering dementia.
content: We have an upset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Joe Biden Has Something Else He’d Like to Transform
description: Next up? Early childhood education.
content: Gail Collins: President Biden has a big speech coming up this week, Bret. Before we delve deep — or, hey, maybe at least deepish — can I use it as an excuse to talk for a minute about Walter Mondale?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Scoop Is Summer Ready
description: This cast aluminum ice cream scoop looks like a cone.
content: A weighty but clever ice cream scoop from the MoMA Design Store made of shiny cast aluminum alloy is something of a trompe l’oeil piece designed by the firm Aruliden to look like an ice cream cone. It makes for a timely addition to the kitchen arsenal and might also please a Mother’s Day recipient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: As Virus Rages Abroad, Biden Promises to Ship Millions of Vaccine Doses
description: President Biden will send up to 60 million doses of AstraZeneca’s vaccine to countries pleading for help, but some see a medicine dropper for “a four-alarm fire.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, under intense pressure to do more to address the surging pandemic abroad, including a humanitarian crisis in India, intends to make up to 60 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine available to other countries, so long as federal regulators deem the doses safe, officials said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: W. Galen Weston, Who Transformed a Family Food Empire, Dies at 80
description: Faced with the task of turning around a nearly bankrupt supermarket chain, he made private-label merchandise fashionable.
content: W. Galen Weston, a polo partner of Prince Charles who transformed and expanded the international food empire founded by his grandfather, a baker, and went on to collect luxury department stores, died on April 12 at his home in Toronto. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: New York Loses House Seat After Coming Up 89 People Short on Census
description: New population figures released on Monday confirmed that after the latest census, New York would lose a congressional seat, but only by the narrowest of margins.
content: New York’s congressional delegation will shrink by one seat after the 2022 election, the Census Bureau announced on Monday, but the state came excruciatingly close to snapping an eight-decade streak of declining representation in Washington: It was 89 residents short, to be precise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Helen Weaver, Chronicler of an Affair With Kerouac, Dies at 89
description: She was a respected translator from French and a writer on astrology, but her magnum opus was a memoir of her time with Kerouac and the Beats.
content: Helen Weaver, who fell in love with Jack Kerouac months before “On the Road” rocketed him into the literary stratosphere, and who 53 years later made a record of their romance in an enduring book of her own, died on April 13 at her home in Woodstock, N.Y. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes
title: A Surprise Ending for the Oscars’ Inclusive Night
description: Six years after #OscarsSoWhite, a diverse roster of artists won awards, though Anthony Hopkins’s win over Chadwick Boseman as best actor surprised many.
content: LOS ANGELES — In a break with tradition, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences decided to end its Oscars ceremony on Sunday with the prize for best actor instead of the one for best picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: A private school in Miami, citing false claims, bars vaccinated teachers from contact with students.
description: Centner Academy advertises its support for “medical freedom from mandated vaccines,” and has recently hosted talks by antivaccine advocates.
content: A private school in the fashionable Design District of Miami sent its faculty and staff a letter last week about getting vaccinated against Covid-19. But unlike institutions that have encouraged and even facilitated vaccination for teachers, the school, Centner Academy, did the opposite: One of its co-founders, Leila Centner, informed employees “with a very heavy heart” that if they chose to get a shot, they would have to stay away from students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: India’s deadly coronavirus surge.
content: India is experiencing a terrible outbreak of the coronavirus, with more than 300,000 new infections and 2,000 deaths per day, up from fewer than 100 deaths per day in February. Experts warn the true death toll is far higher than officially reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: Guard Watched as Man Hanged Himself in Jail, Prosecutors Say
description: Capt. Rebecca Hillman was charged with criminally negligent homicide in the death, which has added to criticism of New York City’s jail system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Jeff Koons Moves to Pace Gallery
description: After years of having his work sold by the Gagosian and Zwirner galleries, the artist aims for a fresh start.
content: In an effort to reboot and to consolidate management of his sales, the mega-artist Jeff Koons is moving from two mega-galleries to one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: The European Union sues AstraZeneca over missing vaccine doses.
description: The legal action escalates a longstanding dispute over shortfalls in deliveries, even as Brussels is seeking to shift to other suppliers.
content: The European Union has sued AstraZeneca over what the bloc has described as delays in shipping hundreds of millions of doses of coronavirus vaccines, a sharp escalation of a longstanding dispute between the bloc and the maker of one of the world’s most important vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla Profit Hits a Quarterly Record
description: The electric-car maker’s performance reflected increasing sales and production around the world.
content: Tesla announced a solid quarterly financial performance on Monday reflecting continuing increases in sales and production around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: A Look at Covid-19 Vaccine ‘Passports,’ Passes and Apps Around the Globe
description: A variety of digital and old-fashioned approaches are being used  to confirm  vaccination for entry to public places. But the world is still far from a universal standard of proof for crossing borders.
content: It is the latest status symbol. Flash it at the people, and you can get access to concerts, sports arenas or long-forbidden restaurant tables. Some day, it may even help you cross a border without having to quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: And the Oscar Goes to … a Film From a Video Game
description: “Colette,” which was featured in the virtual-reality video game Medal of Honor: Above and Beyond, took home the award for best documentary short.
content: It was a night of firsts: First Korean actor to win an Oscar, oldest performer to win best actor, first woman of color to win best director.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany plans to make all adults eligible for vaccination starting in June.
description: German health authorities will allow all adults to sign up for vaccine appointments beginning in June, Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday.
content: German health authorities will allow all adults to sign up for vaccine appointments beginning in June, Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Russia Is Exporting So Much Vaccine
description: Millions of doses of Russia’s pioneering coronavirus vaccine have gone abroad, strengthening the country’s influence at the expense of its people.
content: In recent years, Russia has tried to reassert its global influence in many ways, from military action in Ukraine to meddling in U.S. elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Megan Specia
title: The E.U. May Soon Welcome American Tourists Again. Here’s What to Know.
description: The head of the European Commission said the bloc was working to allow vaccinated visitors from the U.S. this summer. Questions remain about how and when that might happen.
content: BRUSSELS — A yearlong ban on all but the most essential travel from the United States to the European Union may be lifted soon, just in time for summer vacation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Westberg
title: Sweden, Dressed in Summer
description: We’ve shown you Sweden in snow. Now see it in bloom.
content: For as long as I can remember, the forests, lakes and mountains of my native Sweden have been my refuge. Half of the photos from my childhood depict me with an armful of wildflowers or a bucket brimming with — not to mention my face covered with the juices of — blueberries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple will increase its spending in the United States by 20 percent.
description: The company said it would invest more than $1 billion in North Carolina, with a new office in the Raleigh-Durham area and at least 3,000 new jobs there.
content: Apple said on Monday that it would increase its spending in the United States by 20 percent, or $80 billion, over the next five years and that it planned to build a new office in North Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Josh Is the Name, and They Will Fight You for It
description: How “pandemic boredom” led to an internet sensation and a battle royal (with pool noodles) of many Joshes.
content: Josh Swain of Arizona was, of course, joshing. He never really intended to fight anyone who shared his name, but what was he supposed to do? Every time Mr. Swain went to register for a social media account under his name, he was foiled. “It’s always been taken,” Mr. Swain said. What’s even more bizarre: “I have never met a Josh Swain.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Pandemic Lockdowns Cut Pollution, Slowing Snowmelt in South Asia
description: Last year’s lockdowns reduced emissions of soot and other pollutants that accelerate melting, which could make water supplies last longer throughout the coming year.
content: Cleaner skies over South Asia that resulted from pandemic lockdowns last year likely affected the timing of snowmelt in the Indus River basin of Pakistan and India, researchers reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: India continues to shatter case records as it awaits international aid.
description: India’s coronavirus crisis deepened on Monday with the number of new reported cases setting a global record for the fifth consecutive day, as countries, companies and members of the large diaspora pledged to send oxygen and other critical aid.
content: India’s coronavirus crisis deepened on Monday with the number of new reported cases setting a global record for the fifth consecutive day, as countries, companies and members of the large diaspora pledged to send oxygen and other critical aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger and Claire Cain Miller
title: A New Benefit Raises an Old Question: Which Mothers Should Work?
description: A groundbreaking child allowance stirs a debate among Republicans between promoting work and promoting traditional families.
content: American mothers have always been sorted and divided — deemed worthy of aid or not — by race, by class, by marital status, by what their husbands do, by whether they’ve had too many children or not enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: 2021 Oscar Winners: Complete List
description: The complete list of winners for the 93rd Academy Awards.
content: The Academy Awards looked different this year: The red carpet was hemmed, and the after-parties were cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Winning a Housing Lottery and Figuring Out How to Get Out of a Lease
description: The affordable unit was bigger, but also more expensive than her studio. She decided it was worth it.
content: Last fall, Rodica Miller found herself in a somewhat strange situation: She had won an affordable-housing lottery for a one-bedroom apartment just steps from the Roosevelt Island studio where she’d been living since 2018. But moving there would mean a substantial rent increase: from $2,050 a month to $2,468 a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Is an Activist’s Pricey House News? Facebook Alone Decides.
description: The New York Post has complained that Facebook is blocking and downplaying its stories. But the platform doesn’t pay any special deference to journalists.
content: On Wednesday, I learned a new way to get a news article erased from much of the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: Oscars Ratings Plummet, With Fewer Than 10 Million Tuning In
description: Sunday night’s pandemic-restricted telecast drew 58 percent fewer viewers than last year’s record low.
content: LOS ANGELES — For the film industry, which was already fighting to hold its place at the center of American culture, the Nielsen ratings for Sunday night’s 93rd Academy Awards came as a body blow: About 9.85 million people watched the telecast, a 58 percent plunge from last year’s record low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Two nominees took the assignment literally.
description: In one of those you-couldn’t-make-it-up moments, Carey Mulligan and Andra Day, both nominees for best actress, showed up on the red carpet in gold midriff-baring gowns — Mulligan in Valentino haute couture and Day in custom Vera Wang.
content: In one of those you-couldn’t-make-it-up moments, Carey Mulligan and Andra Day, both nominees for best actress, showed up on the red carpet in gold midriff-baring gowns — Mulligan in Valentino haute couture and Day in custom Vera Wang.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: China Censors Chloé Zhao’s Oscar Win, but Fans Find Ways to Rejoice
description: On social media, the director’s fans blurred out her name and turned images on their sides to evade the censors. “People should be celebrating,” one writer said.
content: Chloé Zhao’s historic Oscar win should have been met with jubilation in China, the country of her birth. On Sunday night, she became the first Chinese and woman of color to be named best director, for “Nomadland,” which also took home the prize for best picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Nomadland’ Makes History, and Anthony Hopkins, in Upset, Wins Best Actor
description: Chloé Zhao’s film about the damaged American dream won best picture, best director and best actress. The late Chadwick Boseman, who was considered the frontrunner for best actor, was beat out by Hopkins.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Nomadland,” Chloé Zhao’s meditation on grief and the damaged American dream, won Academy Awards for best picture, director and actress at Sunday night’s surreal ceremony, a stage show broadcast on television about films mostly distributed on the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: The Entangling, Ever-Extending Labyrinth of French Lockdowns
description: Walk the dog? Only one kilometer. Want a raclette maker? Sure. A lamp? Nope. During the pandemic, France’s bureaucracy has hit overdrive, and the French are increasingly fed up.
content: PARIS — Three French lockdowns, and counting, over the past 13 months have been many things, among them a rare opportunity for the formidable national bureaucracy of about 5.6 million public servants to display their gift for the complication of lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: With Navalny in Prison, Russia Turns to Thwarting His Movement
description: Prosecutors have temporarily muzzled the opposition leader’s political groups, banning them from protests and posting on social media. But a court ruling may well make that permanent.
content: MOSCOW — Prosecutors in President Vladimir V. Putin’s government requested on Monday an immediate halt to all public activities by Aleksei A. Navalny’s political groups, in one of the most sweeping legal moves against the Russian opposition in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Biden Forms Task Force to Explore Ways to Help Labor
description: The group will issue recommendations on how the government can use existing authority to help workers join labor unions and bargain collectively.
content: President Biden signed an executive order on Monday creating a White House task force to promote labor organizing, an attempt to use the power of the federal government to reverse a decades-long decline in union membership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Jeffery C. Mays and Dana Rubinstein
title: Women’s Groups Back Wiley, and McGuire Shows His Wealth
description: The New York City mayor’s race has eight weeks to go before the June 22 primary, and endorsements and donations are beginning to help it take shape.
content: Raymond J. McGuire, a trailblazing Black businessman who is trying to parlay his decades of success on Wall Street into a successful run for mayor of New York City, has tried to discourage comparisons to Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire ex-mayor who won office in 2001 as a Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Carol Rosenberg
title: The Supreme Court will decide if C.I.A. black sites are state secrets.
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether the government can block a detainee at Guantánamo Bay from obtaining information from two former C.I.A. contractors involved in torturing him.
content: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether the government can block a detainee at Guantánamo Bay from obtaining information from two former C.I.A. contractors involved in torturing him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Triumph of the Anti-Legislator
description: Representatives Mo Brooks and Marjorie Taylor Greene care more about culture warring than lawmaking. Will Mark McCloskey join them?
content: Don’t look now, but Mark McCloskey is eyeing a run for the open Senate seat in Missouri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: With U.K. cases low, Scotland and Wales reopen restaurants and stores.
description: Scotland and Wales reopened restaurants, cafes, and nonessential shops on Monday, marking the next phase of a gradual relaxation of coronavirus restrictions that have been in place for months.
content: Scotland and Wales reopened restaurants, cafes, and nonessential shops on Monday, marking the next phase of a gradual relaxation of coronavirus restrictions that have been in place for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Different White House, Different Washington
description: Katie Rogers, a White House correspondent, talks about the changes a new administration has brought to the capitol, including a diverse cabinet and a lack of midnight tweets.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China opens an inquiry into Meituan, a takeout-delivery titan.
description: The inquiry, announced with a terse, one-line statement, is the latest move in China’s fast-moving campaign to rein in its internet giants.
content: China’s fast-moving campaign to rein in its internet giants is continuing apace with an antitrust investigation into Meituan, a leading food-delivery app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: The Race to Replace Angela Merkel Is On
description: In Armin Laschet and Annalena Baerbock, voters have a stark choice between continuity and change.
content: BERLIN — For the past two and a half years, since it became clear that Chancellor Angela Merkel would not run for office again, there’s been one great unresolved question in German politics: Who will succeed her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: Census, India, Apple-Facebook: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Urban Farmers Captured on Canvas
description: An exhibition by the painter Elizabeth Downer Riker documents a decade of urban gardening.
content: “Re-Enchanting the City,” an exhibition in Chelsea, highlights the visual record of the many vibrant local farms, community gardens and rooftop plantings around the city by the artist Elizabeth Downer Riker. About 10 years ago she started painting rooftop farms in Long Island City, Queens, and parts of Brooklyn, and then took her oils and canvas to other neighborhoods in the city, and even upstate. The exhibition features 20 of her works, and they are for sale, $1,000 to $2,200.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Court Chides F.B.I., but Re-Approves Warrantless Surveillance Program
description: Newly disclosed episodes in which analysts improperly searched for data about Americans largely came before changes at the bureau.
content: WASHINGTON — For a second year, the nation’s surveillance court has pointed with concern to “widespread violations” by the F.B.I. of rules intended to protect Americans’ privacy when analysts search emails gathered without a warrant — but still signed off on another year of the program, a newly declassified ruling shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Where to Stream ‘Nomadland’ and Other Big Oscar Winners
description: All of the Oscar winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide.
content: Every single Oscar winner is available for home viewers to watch right now, including “Nomadland,” which won major prizes for best picture, best director and best actress, and has been streaming on Hulu for months. The big questions are where, how and how much: Some are exclusive to popular streaming services like Netflix, some are affordable rentals while a couple more recent releases are $19.99, and some can be streamed and bought but not rented while others can be rented but not bought. Sound confusing? The list of Oscar winners below will put you a click away from knowing all the options and discovering whether or not the Academy got it right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Nearing 100 Days, Biden Prepares to Govern Post-Pandemic
description: The president, who has earned high marks for his handling of the outbreak, is moving into a new phase of his administration.
content: When President Biden addresses a joint session of Congress for the first time on Wednesday, rounding the bend on his 100th day in office, he will have a number of progressive achievements to highlight. Chief among them, he’ll most likely play up his aggressive response to the coronavirus pandemic, emphasizing the theme of “shots in arms and money in pockets.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coney Island’s Original Goes Vegan
description: Nathan’s Famous has added a plant-based hot dog to its menu.
content: Like a number of other fast food chains, Nathan’s Famous, known for its hot dogs, has added a vegan option. It entered a partnership with the company Meatless Farm to create a plant-based version of its hot dog. The key to it is Nathan’s proprietary spice blend. (Nathan Handwerker developed his hot dog, made famous on Coney Island, more than 100 years ago.) On its own, the new vegan hot dog lacks snap and succulence, and though the spice comes through, it has a slightly vegetal flavor. But in a classic bun, piled with sauerkraut and slathered with mustard, it passes muster. The vegan hot dog makes its debut Monday online (a package of six plant-based hot dogs with buns and mustard, $49.99) and in the coming weeks at Nathan’s Famous restaurants ($4.99 per hot dog) in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2021 Oscars
description: In between a cinematic entrance and a letdown of an ending, there were breakthroughs, heartbreaks and a wolf howl. It was a strange night.
content: The 93rd Academy Awards were already shaping up to be unusual — delayed because of the pandemic and featuring movies that, for the most part, bypassed theaters for streaming. Then the producers, including Steven Soderbergh and Stacey Sher, were asked to shake up the show. That they did, setting it at Union Station in downtown Los Angeles and upending the order of awards so that best picture was announced earlier than usual and best actor was the last to be revealed. While “Nomadland” won best picture as pundits predicted, hopes were high for a sweep by actors of color, only to be dashed late in the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Ben Shpigel
title: Urban Meyer’s Renewal in Jacksonville
description: After years of disarray, the Jaguars have what the team’s owner called “a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity in football” — the No. 1 pick in the N.F.L. draft and a coach who knows what to do with him.
content: They filed into the first few rows of TIAA Bank Field, 120 staffers from the Jacksonville Jaguars’ business side, sitting there like so many college boosters and alumni Urban Meyer had addressed over the years. He gathered them there on a sunny afternoon in early March, nearly two months after being hired to revive one of the N.F.L.’s more forlorn franchises, to deliver a speech similar in spirit and substance to ones he’d given as the coach at college behemoths like Ohio State and Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Asian Man Who Was Stomped and Kicked in Harlem Is in Critical Condition
description: A Chinese man collecting bottles and cans was kicked in the head, part of a wave of assaults on Asian New Yorkers.
content: A 61-year-old Asian man who was assaulted in East Harlem on Friday night while pushing a grocery cart full of bottles and cans remained in critical but stable condition on Monday morning, the police said, another victim in a rising wave of attacks against Asians in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Anthony Hopkins Accepts Oscar, Paying Tribute to Chadwick Boseman
description: “At 83 years of age I did not expect to get this award,” Hopkins said of his best actor win in a video posted early on Monday morning.
content: About four hours after he won best actor at the 93rd Academy Awards in an upset, Anthony Hopkins delivered his acceptance in a video from Wales, taking a moment to acknowledge the actor who had been widely expected to win posthumously, Chadwick Boseman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whitney Bauck
title: The Preachers ’n’ Sneakers Trend is Alive and Well and Spawning Merch
description: Also a new book that examines the relationship between spirituality and stuff. Here’s what to expect.
content: Ben Kirby started the Instagram account @preachersnsneakers as a gag in 2019. Mr. Kirby, then a 29-year-old MBA student and former Marine, had no idea that the result — images of megachurch pastors decked out in designer gear, juxtaposed with the price tags of their clothes and shoes — would ignite a widespread conversation about materialism in the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Chloé Zhao becomes the first woman of color to win best director.
description: The filmmaker behind “Nomadland” has been winning all season long and is already at work on her next project, the superhero team-up “Eternals.”
content: Chloé Zhao on Sunday became the first woman of color, first Chinese woman and second woman ever to win the Oscar for directing, capping off a historically impressive run of honors she has amassed this awards season for her work on the drama “Nomadland.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti
title: In Setback for Trump, Doug Collins Will Not Run in Georgia in 2022
description: Mr. Collins, a former Republican congressman and ardent defender of former President Trump, was seen as an experienced potential challenger to Senator Raphael Warnock or Gov. Brian Kemp.
content: ATLANTA — Doug Collins, a former U.S. congressman and ardent defender of former President Donald J. Trump, announced on Monday that he would not seek any statewide office in 2022, at once narrowing the field of Republican candidates for Senate in Georgia and removing a potential intraparty challenge to Gov. Brian Kemp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: A Survivor’s Perspective on San Francisco’s Drug Crisis
description: Monday: A poignant voice in the debate over what can be done to combat overdose deaths.
content: Good morning.

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Four Studies of Black Healing’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about Black healing through photographs and narrative essays. Then, they will reflect by creating a one-pager or taking their own photographs.

author: By Benjamin Mueller, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. Sues AstraZeneca Over Missing Vaccine Doses
description: The legal action escalates a longstanding dispute over shortfalls in deliveries, even as Brussels is seeking to shift to other suppliers.
content: The European Union has sued AstraZeneca over what the bloc has described as delays in shipping hundreds of millions of doses of coronavirus vaccines, a sharp escalation of a longstanding dispute between the bloc and the maker of one of the world’s most important vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Karan Deep Singh
title: Amid Second Virus Wave, the World Responds to India’s Distress Call
description: Countries, companies and powerful members of the diaspora have all pledged to pitch in, but it likely won’t be enough to stop the unfolding catastrophe.
content: NEW DELHI — Oxygen generators from Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. Raw material for coronavirus vaccines from the United States. Millions in cash from companies led by Indian-American businessmen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Mezcal With Brooklyn Connections
description: Pelotón de la Muerte makes three mezcals, and it’s owned in part by the Brooklyn chef Danny Mena.
content: Cinco de Mayo is just around the corner, so you might as well stock up on mezcal like everybody else. (Drizly, an e-commerce liquor retailer, reports that mezcal sales were up 600 percent last year.) Danny Mena, a chef who was notably at Hecho en Dumbo and who is now at La Loncheria in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is also a partner in Pelotón de la Muerte, a mezcal company in Mexico that uses mostly wild magueys (a type of agave) and traditional production methods. The company has three distinctive mezcals made in different regions. Mezcal made from maguey espadín, the most common maguey, has a fruity, pineapple aroma and flavor. The maguey criollo is earthier, smokier and woodsy. And the vegan pechuga mezcal, made from criollo and ancho magueys distilled with citrus, has a burnt orange allure. (Pechuga is usually distilled with chicken breast or other meats but Pelotón de la Muerte uses fruit instead.) This mezcal goes into the cure for savory rustic chorizo-style salami made by New England Charcuterie in Waltham, Mass., and sold at La Loncheria ($9 for 5.5 ounces).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Nomadland’ is named best picture as expected.
description: The movie, about a widow who hits the road in the recession-struck American West, also won best director.

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Tyler Perry gets an honorary Oscar.
description: The creator of the popular “Madea” films was recognized for his “cultural influence.”
content: Special-achievement Oscars are seemingly straightforward. Film industry person gets gold-plated bronze dude for doing notable thing.

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: ‘All in All, the Worst Oscars Ever’
description: Readers weighed in on a pared-down pandemic Oscars.
content: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ pared-down pandemic version of the Oscars on Sunday could be described as either incredibly refreshing or incredibly awkward — depending on what you thought of Glenn Close doing Da Butt, among other moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: Where Does a Candle Go When It Burns?
description: Just saying, maybe go easy with the candelabras.
content: Where does a candle go when it burns, anyway? Is it healthy to be breathing in melted candle particles? How concerned should I be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: The Debate Over What ‘Infrastructure’ Is Is Ridiculous
description: Both snarled traffic and a morning without a home health aide can make you late for work.
content: Ask any of the parents who have spent the last year at home with their children, while trying to participate in Zoom meetings, whether child care enables them to show up to work and perform at their best. The direct conflict between children’s need to be cared for during the day and working parents’ need to devote their attention to their jobs exploded into full view during the pandemic, not just for families but for their employers and co-workers. Suddenly it was everyone’s problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo, in Rare Public Appearance, Says: ‘I Didn’t Do Anything Wrong’
description: After months of holding virtual news conferences, Gov. Andrew Cuomo took reporters’ questions in Syracuse, N.Y., and rejected accusations of harassment.
content: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — In recent months, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has striven to convey a sense of normalcy during a period of profound turmoil, holding a series of tightly controlled events where he is often surrounded by aides or supporters, and seldom by reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Which States Will Gain or Lose Seats in the Next Congress
description: Texas and Florida will get more House representatives. California and New York will lose slots. Here’s how the 2020 census redistributes political power.
content: Texas and Florida will get more House representatives. California and New York will lose slots. Here’s how the 2020 census redistributes political power.

description: The White House press secretary, Jen Psaki, said on Monday that the United States would begin sharing its supply of the AstraZeneca vaccine with the world after it passed federal safety reviews.
content: The White House press secretary, Jen Psaki, said on Monday that the United States would begin sharing its supply of the AstraZeneca vaccine with the world after it passed federal safety reviews.

title: To Be Tracked or Not? Apple Is Now Giving Us the Choice.
description: With Apple’s latest mobile software update, we can decide whether apps monitor and share our activities with others. Here’s what to know.
content: If we had a choice, would any of us want to be tracked online for the sake of seeing more relevant digital ads?

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: SiriusXM Is Buying ‘99% Invisible,’ and Street Cred in Podcasting
description: The deal, for one of the industry’s earliest success stories, is the latest salvo in an era of rapid consolidation.
content: Roman Mars’s “99% Invisible,” a hit podcast about the hidden influence of design and architecture that helped solidify resurgent interest in narrative audio when it premiered in 2010, has a new home. SiriusXM, the satellite radio provider, has acquired Mars’s company, 99% Invisible Inc., which is responsible for the podcast, its various spinoffs — including the limited series “Articles of Interest” and “According to Need” — and a best-selling book, “The 99% Invisible City,” released last year.
source.name: The New York Times
